unnormalised: Hey everyone, I've been seeing a lot of confusion online about how to properly write out an Indian residential address, especially for things like online shopping or sending couriers. It can seem a little complicated with all the details needed, so I thought I'd break it down.
normalised: Hey everyone, I've been seeing a lot of confusion online about how to properly write out an Indian residential address, especially for things like online shopping or sending couriers. It can seem a little complicated with all the details needed, so I thought I'd break it down.

unnormalised: First off, the most basic format is usually: Name, followed by the House Number or Name, then the Street Name or Road. So, for example, it could be "Priya Sharma, 12A, MG Road". But that's often just the beginning! In bigger cities, you'll often need to add more details.
normalised: First off, the most basic format is usually: Name, followed by the House Number or Name, then the Street Name or Road. So, for example, it could be "Priya Sharma, twelve A, M-G Road". But that's often just the beginning! In bigger cities, you'll often need to add more details.

unnormalised: After the street, you'll typically include the locality or neighborhood. This helps pinpoint the exact area within a larger city. So, it could become "Priya Sharma, 12A, MG Road, Bandra West". See how that helps narrow it down? And especially in a city like Mumbai, Bandra on its own is not enough!
normalised: After the street, you'll typically include the locality or neighborhood. This helps pinpoint the exact area within a larger city. So, it could become "Priya Sharma, twelve A, M-G Road, Bandra West". See how that helps narrow it down? And especially in a city like Mumbai, Bandra on its own is not enough!

unnormalised: Then comes the city name, followed by the postal code (PIN code). This is super important for accurate delivery! For instance, "Priya Sharma, 12A, MG Road, Bandra West, Mumbai, 400050". The PIN code is usually a 6-digit number, so make sure you get it right!
normalised: Then comes the city name, followed by the postal code (P-I-N code). This is super important for accurate delivery! For instance, "Priya Sharma, twelve A, M-G Road, Bandra West, Mumbai, four hundred thousand and fifty". The P-I-N code is usually a six-digit number, so make sure you get it right!

unnormalised: Sometimes, you might also want to include the apartment name or building name, especially in large apartment complexes. This would go right after the name: "Priya Sharma, 'Sunshine Apartments', 12A, MG Road, Bandra West, Mumbai, 400050". Adding the flat number can also be useful.
normalised: Sometimes, you might also want to include the apartment name or building name, especially in large apartment complexes. This would go right after the name: "Priya Sharma, 'Sunshine Apartments', twelve A, M-G Road, Bandra West, Mumbai, four hundred thousand and fifty". Adding the flat number can also be useful.

unnormalised: Finally, including the state is technically optional if the PIN code is correct, but it doesn't hurt to add it, especially for international shipments! So, the full address might look like this: "Priya Sharma, Flat No 201, 'Sunshine Apartments', 12A, MG Road, Bandra West, Mumbai, Maharashtra, 400050". A common example for Delhi could be something like, "Rakesh Kumar, H.No. 234, Sector 4, Dwarka, New Delhi, Delhi, 110078." See how each part adds more clarity?
